bibl.note: This is a letter from G. W. Martin to Andrew J. Donelson, dated June 31, 1834. Martin has been traveling around the south gaging people's opinions about the government. He writes that they are being misused by their politicians. Martin has many derogatory things to say about the prominent Mississippian politician George Poindexter. He also writes that the people are against the Bank of the U. S.

div.p: I am just returned from a journey of some four to six hundred miles, passing through many of the most interesting country in the state and have had every facility of discovering the un biased if a liberal opinion of the people generally, and I am constrained here to aver there never has been a people more abused, more misrepresented both by their polititians politicians particularly at Washington City, as well by a hot headed set of self important would be great men whose views are supported by some half a dozen people menings millers Bankers if of swelled head
